instructions: Participants were asked to estimate the probability of a replication being significant given an initial significant result.

items.question: Suppose you have run an experiment on 20 Ss, and have obtained a significant result which confirms your theory (z = 2.23, p < .05, two-tailed). You now have cause to run an additional group of 10 Ss. What do you think the probability is that the results will be significant, by a one-tailed test, separately for this group?
